title: Yo-Yo Ma delights San Antonio audience
text:

Photo: Courtesy Mark Horn Image 6 of 6 Itzhak Perlman Itzhak Perlman Yo-Yo Ma delights San Antonio audience 1 / 6 Back to Gallery The San Antonio Symphony on Friday night continued its tradition of bringing the world’s best talents to the city’s stages by presenting cellist Yo-Yo Ma for a sumptuous, emotionally moving account of Antonín Dvorák’s Cello Concerto.
Yo-Yo Ma joins the list of recent appearances here, which includes performances by soprano Renée Fleming, pianist Lang Lang and violinists Joshua Bell and Itzhak Perlman for concerts with the orchestra and recitals.
Given the richness of Yo-Yo Ma’s remarkable career, he can be considered the highest royalty of all.
Related: 41 things to do in S.A. this weekend
He certainly was magic for the sold-out audience of about 1,750 at the Tobin Center for the Performing Arts, plus 400 more people who watched a simulcast outside at the center’s River Walk plaza.
Dvorák composed his last major orchestral piece as his beloved sister-in-law, Josefina Kaunitzova was dying. The music is full of homesickness and longing, with a revised final coda written as a lament.
Yo-Yo Ma made the concerto his own emotional journey, playing at times with a deceptive sense of abandon that, in reality, was disciplined, openhearted expression.
He poured everything he had into the piece, as if determined to give San Antonio his best Dvorák concerto ever. His supreme confidence spread throughout the orchestra, which met him with equal eloquence, such as French horn player Jeff Garza in the first movement’s key solo passage, and flutist Martha Long in her second-movement duet with Yo-Yo Ma.
Time seemed to stand still in the moving adagio, Dvorák’s tribute to a lost love.
Yo-Yo Ma’s encore was an example of his humbleness. He sat among the orchestra’s seven cello players for a lovely performance of Heitor Villa-Lobos’ Bachianas brasileiras No. 5. The cellists mainly provided a pizzicato backdrop to the famous melody played by Yo-Yo Ma.
The concert’s highlight before the Dvorák was a sharp performance of Sergei Rachmaninoff’s Symphonic Dances, a trove of soaring melodies that alternate between muscular, testosterone-driven themes and tender, wistful passages. The smooth transitions helped create a kind of male-female interplay, or dance. The piece begs for high degrees of orchestral talent. The symphony delivered with insightful phrasing and coloration under the baton of Music Director Sebastian Lang-Lessing. Harvey Pittel delivered the famous saxophone solo.
